title: Is the Golden Rule in Bible? - Quora

response.answer_text: “The Golden Rule”, Do unto others as you would have them do unto you”, is taken as a quote from the Bible, or specifically from Jesus (per the Biblical account), both in Luke 6:31 and Matthew 7:12. The exact quote is from the Luke version, and, if the accounts are to believed, they happened at the same time (Sermon on the Mount), but in different contexts, yet with the same meaning. The Luke account is in references to how to treat enemies. The Matthew account, it is with asking and receiving, and how God treats your requests as a son. The Matthew account is interesting because it also says this statement “sums up the Law and the Prophets”, i.e. Old Testament. That is later referenced to the one of the two greatest commandments (Mark 12:29–31), “love your neighbor as yourself”, which is a step up from just action, as Jesus also stepped up other specific commandments. But these two statements are obviously very closely linked. But, about 500 years earlier (with less dated accuracy, but well believed), Confucius is quoted as saying “Do not impose on others what you do not wish for yourself”. That is subtly different from the Golden Rule. Not doing something you wouldn’t want done to you Is passive. “Don’t do this”. The Golden Rule is active: Do this, as if you were that person. But, the “Love your neighbor as yourself” didn’t originate with Jesus when he was walking around as a man. That is actually much older. Somewhere estimated around 1550 BC (1000+ years before Confucius), Moses is credited with recording God’s Word/Laws, starting with the 10 Commandments, but with a lot more. In Leviticus 19:18, he records “but love your neighbor as yourself”, in contrast to “don’t seek revenge or bear a grudge. To be thorough, There is an obscure Egyptian peasant story, estimated around 1800 BC (so possibly of Hebrew origin as well, if you believe the biblical account of 430 years in Egypt) that can be construed to be similar, but is worded a little more closely to the Confucius statement, or more of a lead by example (the text is very brief and has less detail of “language” about it). So, it is not in just in the Bible, it is from the Bible, directly as a quote, and likely a tenet of the Hebrew from much, much earlier.

The phrase, the "Golden Rule," in and of itself does NOT appear in the Bible. The phrase is a figure of speech. It is a label that believers and Bible students have given to a specific biblical Scripture. That being Matthew 7:12: As It Is Written: “Therefore, whatever you want men to do to you, do also to them, for this is the Law and the Prophets.(Matthew 7:12 NKJV) The reason that believers and Bible students refer to this is the golden rule is because Messiah said that this rule explains the point of every other biblical law out there. The whole point of all the rules is to teach you how to love God with all of your being, and how to love your neighbor as yourself. The "Golden Rule" is just a label to remind believers in conversation to remember this concept. It's the same idea as referring to, "The Lord's Prayer." Believers and Bible students know that when you use that term you are either referring to the Bible passages of Matthew 6:9-15, or John 17; but the phrase, "The Lord's Prayer." Does not actually appear in a biblical verse. It's just a label given to identify that important concept and those two Scripture passages to other believers in conversation.
